title: Remote ischaemic preconditioning versus no remote ischaemic preconditioning for vascular and endovascular surgical procedures
authors: Liang, F; Liu, S; Liu, G; Liu, H; Wang, Q; Song, B; Yao, L

response.output:
Is temporary blockage of blood flow to a distant part of the body (remote ischaemic preconditioning) beneficial compared with no blockage for people undergoing major blood‑vessel surgery?

Key messages  
– Remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC) is a short, harmless blockage of blood flow to an arm or leg. It probably does not change the risk of death around the time of surgery, heart attack (damage to the heart muscle), kidney problems, stroke (brain injury from reduced blood flow), loss of a limb, how long you stay in hospital, or how long the operation takes.  
– The 14 studies we looked at were randomised controlled trials of moderate quality. Because there were few studies and they differed in participants and how RIPC was given, we cannot completely rule out small benefits or harms.  
– Larger, well‑designed trials are needed to find out whether RIPC offers any real advantage for patients having major vascular or endovascular surgery.

What health problems are associated with major vascular and endovascular surgery?  
People who need major operations on large blood vessels – for example, repairing an aortic aneurysm or opening blocked arteries – face serious complications. Even with modern care, they can experience death (mortality) or major health problems after the operation. Common complications include heart attacks, kidney problems (when the kidneys do not work well), strokes, loss of a limb, and longer stays in hospital.

What is remote ischaemic preconditioning and why might it help?  
Remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC) is a technique where we briefly stop blood flow to a part of the body that is not being operated on, using a blood‑pressure cuff on an arm or leg. This short, controlled blockage is thought to “train” the body’s cells to survive longer periods of reduced blood flow (ischaemia) that can occur during surgery. In simple terms, it gives the body a tiny, safe stress so that it can protect its organs when a bigger stress happens during the operation.

What did we want to find out?  
We set out to discover whether using RIPC before planned major vascular or endovascular surgery makes a difference compared with not using it. Specifically, we wanted to know if RIPC reduces the risk of death around the time of surgery, heart attacks, kidney problems, strokes, loss of a limb, length of hospital stay, and the time needed for the operation or anaesthesia. We also looked for any harms.

How did we find the evidence?  
We searched several databases for randomised controlled trials that compared RIPC with no preconditioning in people undergoing elective major vascular or endovascular surgery. We combined the results using statistical methods and rated our confidence in the evidence with the GRADE system, a standard way of judging how sure we can be about the findings.

What did we find?  
We identified 14 trials that together enrolled 1,295 participants (average age 65‑76 years; 84 % men). All trials compare a short pause of blood flow to a limb with no preconditioning. Our pooled analysis shows that RIPC probably makes little or no difference to the main outcomes after surgery. It probably does not change the risk of death around the time of surgery, heart attacks, kidney problems, strokes, or loss of a limb. It also probably does not affect how long people stay in hospital or how long the operation or anaesthetic takes.

What are the limitations of the evidence?  
We are fairly sure about these findings, but only a few studies were available. The participants and the way RIPC was given differed between studies, and the small number of trials could make any benefit look larger than it really is.

How current is the evidence?  
This review updates our previous work and includes all relevant studies up to April 2022.
